canonical_explanation.text: Motion in a plane requires vector analysis. Scalars have only magnitude (mass, temperature, speed), while vectors have both magnitude and direction (displacement, velocity, force). Vectors are added using the triangle law or parallelogram law. The resultant of two vectors A and B making angle θ is R = √(A² + B² + 2AB cos θ), with direction tan α = B sin θ/(A + B cos θ). Any vector can be resolved into perpendicular components: Aₓ = A cos θ, Aᵧ = A sin θ. The scalar (dot) product of two vectors A·B = AB cos θ gives a scalar; it is used in calculating work (W = F·d). The vector (cross) product A×B = AB sin θ n̂ gives a vector perpendicular to both; it is used in torque (τ = r×F). Projectile motion is the motion of an object thrown near Earth's surface under gravity, with no horizontal acceleration and vertical acceleration g downward. For a projectile launched at angle θ with speed u: horizontal range R = u² sin 2θ/g, maximum height H = u² sin²θ/(2g), time of flight T = 2u sin θ/g. Maximum range occurs at θ = 45°. In uniform circular motion, the speed is constant but direction changes continuously, producing centripetal acceleration aᵢ = v²/r = ω²r directed toward the center. Angular velocity ω = 2π/T = 2πf, and v = ωr. Relative velocity of A with respect to B is v_AB = v_A − v_B, and this can be extended to two dimensions using vector subtraction.
rules: Resultant of two vectors: R = √(A² + B² + 2AB cos θ).
Components: Aₓ = A cos θ, Aᵧ = A sin θ.
Dot product: A·B = AB cos θ = AₓBₓ + AᵧBᵧ + A_zB_z.
Cross product magnitude: |A×B| = AB sin θ.
Projectile range: R = u² sin 2θ / g; maximum at θ = 45°.
Time of flight: T = 2u sin θ / g.
Equation of trajectory: y = x tan θ − gx²/(2u² cos²θ).
Centripetal acceleration: a = v²/r = ω²r, directed toward center.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a scalar quantity?
questions.explanation_correct: Speed is a scalar quantity as it has only magnitude. Displacement, velocity, and acceleration are all vectors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Speed is the magnitude of velocity and has no direction, making it a scalar. The others are vectors.

questions.question_text: The resultant of two equal forces F acting at right angles to each other is:
questions.explanation_correct: R = √(F² + F² + 2F² cos 90°) = √(2F²) = F√2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the parallelogram law with θ = 90°: R = √(F² + F²) = F√2.

questions.question_text: Two forces of 3 N and 4 N act on a body. The maximum possible resultant is:
questions.explanation_correct: Maximum resultant occurs when forces are in the same direction: R_max = 3 + 4 = 7 N.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Maximum resultant = A + B (when θ = 0°) = 3 + 4 = 7 N. Minimum resultant = |A − B| = 1 N.

questions.question_text: Two vectors of magnitudes 5 and 12 act at an angle of 90° to each other. The magnitude of the resultant is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: At 90°, R = √(A² + B²) = √(25 + 144) = 13, not the simple sum (17) or difference (7).

questions.question_text: A vector of magnitude 10 makes an angle of 60° with the x-axis. Its x and y components are:
questions.explanation_incorrect: x-component = A cos θ = 5; y-component = A sin θ = 5√3.

questions.question_text: If A = 3î + 4ĵ and B = 4î − 3ĵ, then A + B is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vector addition: add corresponding components. (3+4)î + (4+(−3))ĵ = 7î + ĵ.

questions.question_text: Two forces of equal magnitude F act on a body. If the resultant force has a magnitude equal to F, the angle between the forces is:
questions.explanation_correct: R² = F² + F² + 2F² cos θ = F². So 2F²(1 + cos θ) = F², giving cos θ = −1/2, θ = 120°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Setting R = F: F² = 2F² + 2F² cos θ → cos θ = −1/2 → θ = 120°.

questions.question_text: The magnitude of vector A = 2î − 3ĵ + 6k̂ is:
questions.explanation_correct: |A| = √(4 + 9 + 36) = √49 = 7. Note: options B and D are the same value.

questions.question_text: The unit vector along the x-axis is denoted by:
questions.explanation_correct: î is the unit vector along the x-axis. ĵ is along y-axis and k̂ is along z-axis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By convention, î, ĵ, k̂ are unit vectors along x, y, z axes respectively.

questions.question_text: The resultant of two vectors P and Q is perpendicular to P and has magnitude equal to half of Q. The angle between P and Q is:
questions.explanation_correct: If R ⊥ P, then R² + P² = Q² (Pythagoras). R = Q/2, so Q²/4 + P² = Q². P² = 3Q²/4, P = Q√3/2. tan 90° = Q sin θ/(P + Q cos θ) → P + Q cos θ = 0 → cos θ = −P/Q = −√3/2. θ = 150°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the condition that resultant is perpendicular to P: P + Q cos θ = 0, so cos θ = −P/Q. With R = Q/2 and Pythagoras: P = Q√3/2. Thus cos θ = −√3/2, giving θ = 150°.

questions.question_text: The dot product of two perpendicular vectors is:
questions.explanation_correct: A·B = AB cos 90° = 0. The dot product of perpendicular vectors is always zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since cos 90° = 0, the scalar product of two perpendicular vectors vanishes.

questions.question_text: The cross product of two parallel vectors is:
questions.explanation_correct: |A×B| = AB sin 0° = 0. The cross product of parallel vectors is a zero vector.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since sin 0° = 0, the cross product of parallel (or anti-parallel) vectors is zero.

questions.question_text: î · ĵ equals:
questions.explanation_correct: î and ĵ are perpendicular unit vectors, so î · ĵ = (1)(1) cos 90° = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dot product of perpendicular unit vectors is zero. î × ĵ = k̂ (cross product), but î · ĵ = 0.

questions.question_text: If A = 2î + 3ĵ and B = 3î + 2ĵ, then A · B is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dot product = sum of products of corresponding components: 2×3 + 3×2 = 12.

questions.question_text: î × ĵ equals:
questions.explanation_correct: By the right-hand rule, î × ĵ = k̂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: î × ĵ = k̂ (right-hand rule). Note that ĵ × î = −k̂ (cross product is anti-commutative).

questions.question_text: The angle between vectors A = î + ĵ and B = î − ĵ is:
questions.explanation_correct: A · B = (1)(1) + (1)(−1) = 0. Since dot product is zero, the vectors are perpendicular (90°).

questions.question_text: If A × B = 0 and A · B = AB, then the angle between A and B is:
questions.explanation_correct: A × B = 0 means sin θ = 0, and A · B = AB means cos θ = 1. Both conditions give θ = 0° (parallel vectors).
questions.explanation_incorrect: sin θ = 0 gives θ = 0° or 180°. cos θ = 1 gives θ = 0°. The only common solution is θ = 0°.

questions.question_text: If |A × B| = A · B, the angle between A and B is:
questions.explanation_correct: AB sin θ = AB cos θ → tan θ = 1 → θ = 45°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: |A×B| = AB sin θ and A·B = AB cos θ. Setting them equal: tan θ = 1, so θ = 45°.

questions.question_text: If A = 2î + ĵ + k̂ and B = î − ĵ + 2k̂, then A × B is:
The work done by a force F = 3î + 4ĵ N in displacing a body by d = 4î − 3ĵ m is:
questions.explanation_correct: W = F · d = (3)(4) + (4)(−3) = 12 − 12 = 0 J. The force is perpendicular to the displacement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: W = F · d = 3×4 + 4×(−3) = 0 J. The force and displacement are perpendicular.

questions.question_text: In projectile motion, the acceleration along the horizontal direction is:
questions.explanation_correct: In projectile motion (neglecting air resistance), the only acceleration is g vertically downward. There is no horizontal acceleration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The horizontal component of velocity remains constant as there is no horizontal force (ignoring air resistance).

questions.question_text: The path of a projectile is:
questions.explanation_correct: The trajectory of a projectile is a parabola: y = x tan θ − gx²/(2u² cos²θ).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Under constant gravitational acceleration, the combined horizontal and vertical motions trace a parabolic path.

questions.question_text: For maximum range of a projectile on level ground, the angle of projection should be:
questions.explanation_correct: Range R = u² sin 2θ/g. R is maximum when sin 2θ = 1, i.e., 2θ = 90°, θ = 45°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since R ∝ sin 2θ and sin 2θ is maximum (= 1) at 2θ = 90°, the optimal angle is 45°.

questions.question_text: A ball is thrown at 20 m/s at 30° to the horizontal. The maximum height reached is (g = 10 m/s²):
A projectile is launched at 45° with speed 40 m/s. Its horizontal range is (g = 10 m/s²):
The time of flight of a projectile thrown at 60° with speed 20 m/s is (g = 10 m/s²):
Two projectiles are thrown with the same speed but at angles 30° and 60° to the horizontal. Their ranges are:
questions.explanation_correct: R₁ ∝ sin 60° = sin(2×30°) and R₂ ∝ sin 120° = sin(2×60°). Since sin 60° = sin 120°, the ranges are equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Complementary angles (30° and 60°) give the same range because sin 2θ = sin 2(90°−θ).

questions.question_text: At the highest point of a projectile's trajectory, the velocity is:
questions.explanation_correct: At the highest point, the vertical component of velocity is zero. Only the horizontal component u cos θ remains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The vertical velocity is zero at the top, but the horizontal velocity u cos θ persists throughout the motion.

questions.question_text: If the range and maximum height of a projectile are equal, the angle of projection is:
questions.explanation_correct: R = H: u² sin 2θ/g = u² sin²θ/(2g). 2 sin θ cos θ = sin²θ/2. 4 cos θ = sin θ. tan θ = 4. θ = tan⁻¹(4).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Setting R = H: 2 sin θ cos θ = sin²θ/2. Simplifying: tan θ = 4, so θ = tan⁻¹(4) ≈ 76°.

questions.question_text: A ball is projected horizontally from the top of a building 80 m high with velocity 20 m/s. It hits the ground at a horizontal distance of (g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: Time to fall: t = √(2h/g) = √(160/10) = 4 s. Horizontal distance = 20 × 4 = 80 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Time of flight = √(2×80/10) = 4 s. Range = horizontal velocity × time = 20 × 4 = 80 m.

questions.question_text: In uniform circular motion, the acceleration is directed:
questions.explanation_correct: In uniform circular motion, centripetal acceleration is always directed toward the center of the circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The acceleration that changes the direction of velocity in circular motion points radially inward (centripetal).

questions.question_text: The SI unit of angular velocity is:
questions.explanation_correct: Angular velocity is measured in radians per second (rad/s) in SI units.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Although degree/s and rev/s are used, the SI unit is rad/s.

questions.question_text: A particle moves in a circle of radius 2 m with a speed of 6 m/s. The centripetal acceleration is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Centripetal acceleration = v²/r = 6²/2 = 18 m/s².

questions.question_text: The angular velocity of the hour hand of a clock is:
questions.explanation_correct: Hour hand completes one revolution (2π rad) in 12 hours = 43200 s. ω = 2π/43200 = π/21600 rad/s.

questions.question_text: A body moves in a circular path of radius 0.5 m with a time period of 2 s. The linear speed is:
If the speed of a particle in circular motion is doubled while the radius is halved, the centripetal acceleration becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: a = v²/r. New a' = (2v)²/(r/2) = 4v²/(r/2) = 8v²/r = 8a.
questions.explanation_incorrect: a' = (2v)²/(r/2) = 4v² × 2/r = 8v²/r = 8 times the original acceleration.

questions.question_text: A stone tied to a string of length 1 m is whirled in a horizontal circle at 2 rev/s. The centripetal acceleration is:
questions.explanation_correct: ω = 2πf = 2π × 2 = 4π rad/s. a = ω²r = (4π)² × 1 = 16π² m/s².
questions.explanation_incorrect: ω = 2π × 2 = 4π rad/s. a = ω²r = 16π² × 1 = 16π² ≈ 158 m/s².

questions.question_text: In uniform circular motion, the velocity and acceleration are:

options.text: Constant in magnitude but changing in direction

questions.explanation_correct: In UCM, speed (magnitude of velocity) and magnitude of centripetal acceleration are constant, but both velocity and acceleration vectors continuously change direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Speed is constant but velocity (a vector) changes direction. Centripetal acceleration magnitude v²/r is constant but its direction changes.

questions.question_text: The relation between linear velocity v, angular velocity ω, and radius r is:
questions.explanation_correct: The linear speed and angular speed are related by v = ωr, or in vector form v = ω × r.
questions.explanation_incorrect: v = ωr is the fundamental relation. v = ω²r is centripetal acceleration divided by ω.

questions.question_text: The time period and frequency of circular motion are related as:
questions.explanation_correct: Time period T is the reciprocal of frequency f: T = 1/f.
questions.explanation_incorrect: T and f are inversely related: T = 1/f. ω = 2πf = 2π/T.

questions.question_text: The relative velocity of A with respect to B is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: Relative velocity of A with respect to B is v_AB = v_A − v_B (vector subtraction).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Relative velocity is obtained by vector subtraction: v_AB = v_A − v_B.

questions.question_text: Two cars move in the same direction with velocities 60 km/h and 40 km/h. The velocity of the faster car relative to the slower one is:
questions.explanation_correct: v_rel = 60 − 40 = 20 km/h in the direction of motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When moving in the same direction, relative velocity = difference = 60 − 40 = 20 km/h.

questions.question_text: Two trains move toward each other at 60 km/h and 40 km/h. The velocity of approach is:
questions.explanation_correct: When moving toward each other, relative velocity = sum = 60 + 40 = 100 km/h.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For objects moving in opposite directions, relative speed = sum of speeds = 60 + 40 = 100 km/h.

questions.question_text: Rain falls vertically at 10 m/s. A person walks at 10 m/s. The rain appears to the person to fall at an angle θ to the vertical where θ is:
questions.explanation_correct: tan θ = v_person/v_rain = 10/10 = 1. θ = 45°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The rain's relative velocity has horizontal component = walking speed and vertical = rain speed. tan θ = 10/10 = 1, so θ = 45°.

questions.question_text: A boat can travel at 5 m/s in still water. It crosses a river flowing at 3 m/s. If the boat points straight across, the resultant speed is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: The boat's velocity and river's velocity are perpendicular, so resultant = √(25 + 9) = √34 m/s.

questions.question_text: A river flows east at 4 km/h. A swimmer swims at 3 km/h relative to water pointing due north. The actual speed of the swimmer is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Perpendicular velocities add as vectors: √(9 + 16) = 5 km/h.

questions.question_text: To cross a river of width d in minimum time, a swimmer should swim:
questions.explanation_correct: To minimize time, swim perpendicular to the flow so that the full swimming speed contributes to crossing the width. t_min = d/v_swimmer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Swimming perpendicular maximizes the component of velocity across the river, giving minimum crossing time.

questions.question_text: A bird flies north at 40 km/h in still air. Wind blows from north to south at 20 km/h. The bird's ground speed is:
questions.explanation_correct: Bird velocity = 40 km/h north. Wind = 20 km/h south = −20 km/h north. Ground speed = 40 − 20 = 20 km/h north.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The wind opposes the bird. Ground speed = bird speed − wind speed = 40 − 20 = 20 km/h.

questions.question_text: Two objects A and B move perpendicular to each other with speeds 3 m/s and 4 m/s respectively. The magnitude of velocity of A relative to B is:
questions.explanation_correct: |v_AB| = |v_A − v_B| = √(3² + 4²) = √25 = 5 m/s (since v_A and v_B are perpendicular).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since the velocities are perpendicular: |v_A − v_B| = √(9 + 16) = 5 m/s.

questions.question_text: A man walks due east at 4 km/h. Rain appears to fall at 30° from vertical toward him. The speed of rain is:
questions.explanation_correct: tan 30° = v_man/v_rain_vertical. v_rain_vertical = 4/tan 30° = 4√3 km/h. v_rain = √(4² + (4√3)²) = √(16+48) = √64 = 8 km/h. But the rain appears at 30° from vertical, so tan 30° = horizontal component/vertical = 4/v_vertical → v_vertical = 4/tan 30° = 4√3. Total rain speed = v_vertical/cos 30° = 4√3/(√3/2) = 8 km/h. Actually: if rain falls vertically at v_r and appears at 30°, then tan 30° = 4/v_r → v_r = 4/tan 30° = 4√3. Speed of rain = v_r = 4√3. Hmm, let me reconsider. Rain speed = √(v_r² + 0²) = v_r = 4√3 if falling vertically. So answer should be 4√3. But wait - the actual rain speed in the reference frame is 4√3 km/h vertically. The answer is A: 4√3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: tan 30° = v_man/v_rain. v_rain = v_man/tan 30° = 4/(1/√3) = 4√3 km/h.
